title: Is publishing a book on Amazon Kindle Direct Publishing still considered self-publishing? - Quora

response.answer_text: Self-publishing isn’t about the platforms you use to publish your book, but rather it’s about who pays for publishing it. If you are publishing under your own ISBN and have done all the necessary work to publish it, then it’s self-publishing. If you have hired a hybrid or vanity publisher to help you polish the book and it’s being published under their ISBN, because you have paid for the services rendered, it’s still self-publishing (in this case, sometimes referred to as “indie publishing” too). If you submitted your book to a publisher or small press and they took on the risk and expense of publishing your work so that you don’t have to pay for any of the services rendered, then you are no longer self-publishing. If you found a literary agent willing to “shop” your book around to publishers, you are going the “traditional” publishing route and are definitely not self-publishing. Just a word of caution, though. Hybrid and vanity publishers are not one and the same. Vanity publishers will tell you that your book is the best thing since sliced bread, and they’ll publish it for you as long as you have the funds to pay for it. They provide little guidance or direction as to how to improve the book and once it’s in your hands, they only want to hear from you when you’re ready to order more (over-priced) books from them or to buy one of their marketing packages. A hybrid publisher, on the other hand, partners with you to create the best finished product possible. They provide guidance and direction to you so that you are able to market and sell your book in ways that work for you. Regardless of which publishing model you’re using, all publishers may use Amazon’s KDP to get books on Amazon.

Yes. Self-publishing is when you do all the leg work yourself or pay others to do it (that’s what a publisher does, they pay employees to design covers, edit, open the mail, answer the phones). Like self-publish is what happens when you go to a third party who has their own web site but doesn’t put printed books into stores at no cost to you. That is basically the same as self-publishing, except you have no control and make less money. A true publisher prints book at no cost to the author and puts them on the racks and shelves at Barnes & Noble because they have a distribution contract. As a self-publisher you can not get your books into wide distribution without advertising money. The best you can do is a few on consignment locally. Traditional publishers, self-publishers, “like self-publishers” and those who opt for Kindle’s Expanded Distribution all have one thing in common: They all go through Ingram Content for world-wide distributions on a PAID ORDER basis from book stores. A book store has their data base and can order any book from the Dictionary to YOUR self-published book if you opted for Expanded Distribution or went through Ingram Spark. But there has to be a paying customer ordering that book. Then Lightning source will print it and Ingram will send it out with their regular orders to that dealer.

It is, even though the publishing industry is undergoing significant changes. The process now is often collaborative between author and publisher, especially on things like publicity. But to me there is still a bright line between traditional and self (sometimes called indie) publishing. In self publishing the author has control over the process, decides the format of the book, how and where it is sold and how much to charge. The income comes to the author unless there is a cooperative arrangement with the printer. KDP helps structure the process. But the decisions are yours as the author. So yes, though sophisticated, KDP is still self-publishing.

No. Amazon KDP is a printing company. You present them with your book and they make it available for people to buy. That’s not publishing because they make zero effort to promote and advertise the book, to persuade the public it is worth buying. Of course, sales and marketing are what publishing is all about, and very, very few authors do that successfully for themselves. I believe J K Rowling has some success… The term ‘self-publishing’ is not very helpful. Authors who are not part of the traditional book trade are better labelled as independent.

No. I don’t do the publishing. I don’t pay for it so its not a vanity press which is self-publishing. Some people get this wrong because Amazon is a new model of Publishing House, one that doesn’t offer perks life free editing, free covers, and free promotion. Amazon is still a publisher. Among other things.

It is self publishing. However, Amazon calls it Independent Publishing. This is because a lot of people like our company and me for example will publish a book for someone else using Kindle. So it’s not always self publishing, often a professional service such as ours will do the publishing for a client instead. We are thus considered to be an independent or “indie” publisher on Kindle.

Yes, but…. ‘Self-publishing’ also includes vanity publishers, who charge authors to do all the work for them. Hence ‘Indie’ or ‘Independent Publishing’ coming to describe those who do it totally themselves. The problem is, when people discuss self-publishing, they tend to mean vanity publishing. And the discussion gets confused. If you publish to KDP and do all the work yourself, then call yourself an Indie. (We buy our covers, pay for editing and proofreading, and write our own blurbs.)

Yes, it is self-publishing. I have a book I released that way and have earned enough to buy a couple of pizzas, so it’s at least better than the expensive vanity publishing. But don’t flatter yourself if you have a Kindle Direct book out there. It’s still self-published.

Yes, contrary to what many people will tell you. If you write a book and pay for it it to be designed and formatted, or do it yourself; do or pay for all the publicity and marketing; pay for printing and distribution, then you are self-publishing, no matter if it’s called Independent.

Self-publishing is a broad general term that pretty much covers anything that is not a traditional major publishing house contract. There are specific types of self-publishing, and putting up your book on Amazon KDP is certainly one of the means to that end.
No. Amazon is the single largest corporation in publishing so using them as your publisher is neither independent or self-publishing. It is, by definition, dependent publishing.
Yes, self publishing is putting your own book out there on any number of platforms including Amazon.
